The Johns Hopkins Baseball
Team defeated the strong nine of
the Catholic Univesity on Saturday by the score of 4 to 3, in one
of the closest and most exciting
games of the season. The game
resolved itself intO a pitchers'
battle between Teddy Welliver of
Hopkins and Kendrick of Catholic University, with Welliver having the best of it all the way
through. The young Hopkins'
moundsman held his opponents to
four scattered hits and sent
eleven men back to the bench via
the strike-out route. In two innings, the first and the third, he
fanned all three batters, while he
made two of them whiff in the
seventh period. Kendrick, also
had eleven strike-outs to his credit, but most of the third strikes
he threw were called and many
of them were very close decisions.

So intense is the patriotic impulse of the men under 21 years of
age in the colleges of America to
get into war service that the War
Department in cooperation with
the leading educators of the country has worked out a plan that
may prove the first step toward a
system of voluntary military
training of universal application.
The Secretary of War's announcement on the subject covers
for the present only the colleges
and prescribes that military instruction under officers and noncommissioned officers of the United States Army be given in
every institution of college grade
where 100 or more able-bodied students over the age of 18 may voluntary enroll for such instruction.
From all sides has come word to
Washington that men were leaving the colleges to enlist in the
army, that the youngsters were
not waiting for the draft and that
such depletion was seriously
threatening the continued existence of many colleges. In order,
therefore, to keep together the
men of education from whom, of
course, future officers must be
made, in order to give them a
start in military service and at
the same time enable the colleges
to continue with other branches
of the educational curriculum, the
new plan has been evolved and
will be put into operation in September next.
For with a plethora of men for
the army between the age of 21
and 31 and with the inevitable
loss on the battlefield of young
men on whom time and money has
been spent for higher education, it
would be shortsighted national
policy to permit the breaking up
of any of the colleges.
The idea of extending the plan
to secondary schools has been discussed but no conclusion has been
reached. It is feared that there
would not be enough equipment or
officers to handle the problem if
the young men in the high schools,
too, were enrolled. Later on, however, some such scheme may be
developed.

Georgetown University carried
off the honors of the annual S. A.
I. A. A. Track Meet, at Homewood

Virginia Polytechnic Institute

second.

Gray, managing to haul in four

A Hopkins Tradition Maintained.
Lehigh came to Homewood last Saturday with confidence and the
,
lacrosse championship; Lehigh left Homewood about two hours later
with neither joy nor the championship. The old Hopkins spirit
swelled up in the hearts of Captain Schmidt and his men and swept
the ex-champions off their feet. The so-called weak attack of the
Black and Blue crashed through the Lehigh defense three times before
the game was fairly started. After the first minute of play, there
was never any doubt that the old blue banner was going to adorn
the walls of the Barn for many months to come. It was a brilliant,
glorious, clean-cut victory. It was an eloquent tribute to the coaching system of Hopkins lacrosse, to the loyalty and conscientious
efforts of every member of the team. Hopkins men—in trench and
camp, in France and the States—will learn with real pride and
whole-hearted satisfaction that the new Hopkins men have maintained an old cherished tradition.

An Appreciation.
When Major Guild was elected to the -Omicron Delta Kappa
Circle, it was clearly shown that besides having gained the hearty
cooperation of the faculty, he has won his way into the hearts of
the students themselves. The Circle, which is the most particularly
representative body in the University (for it is composed of men
who have attained distinction in all branches of university activity)
has expressed by its action the high esteem in which our commandant is held by the undergraduates.
The faculty has long lent its support to all Major Guild's plans;
for example, when the military recitations took precedence over all
other classes. The students, also,'have come to regard Major Guild—
strict disciplinarian as he is—with the utmost admiration. He
.has given us a battalion of which we may well be proud, a battalion
which is most proficient in military science, and—what is more—a
battalion with some spirit. Whatever efficiency and fame the Hopkins Battalion has attained this year is directly attributable to the
untiring and unceasing efforts of Major Guild.

Raisons d'Etre of Facts.
•

If there is any one single reason for the publication .of the series
of "facts" in these columns it is the additional fact that the athletic
authorities at the University have never felt it necessary to explain
or defend these "facts." The athletic management seems to feel
that, after its mechanical and meaningless annual election, it is absolutely independent and irresponsible. We feel—without the least
personal embitterment and without the least claim of willful negligence—that it is equally inefficient and unsatisfactory and unwilling
or unfit to adjust itself to the changed conditions of war-times.

At the outset, we beg to emphasize that the publication of "facts"
was never aimed at any individual athletic authority, but at the
athletic system. We had no mysterious ulterior purpose. It was
our single object to give publicity to certain conditions and. circumstances which the authorities never saw fit to divulge to the
mere members.. We believe that through publicity alone can the
interest and the sense of responsibility of all members of the Athletic
Association be aroused and sustained. We believe that it is quite
impossible to approve or disapprove the measures and policies of
our representatives unless we know what they have done and what
they are doing. It is by no means our purpose to detract in any
way from the splendid record of our recognized spring team; for
them we have only unstinted praise.

Now, we are perfectly aware of the Government's whole-hearted
endorsement of intercollegiate athletics during the war. But we
believe that the Government demands, at the same time, increased
economy and efficiency in athletic management; which our own athletic authorities have entirely failed to recognize and enforce.
The Athletic Association has not showed any reasonable tendency to economize. It has arranged long trips, conspicuous among
which are those to Providence and to West Point. It has not withdrawn.the annual appropriation of $75 to the tennis team when it
was perfectly aware that there was no tennis team (we might call
it a tennis clique). It failed to recognize the opportunity to save
$35 by cancelling the Randolph-Macon game; it preferred to pay
$70 and to play the game in the rain before a crowd of three people.
We believe that the members of the Athletic Association would be
interested in a complete, financial statement of the expenditures for
the year, which might be published in these columns and enable the
members to mold their own judgment on the question of economy
-in athletics.
The Athletic Association has not lived up to the standard of
efficiency which was set up for it at the end of last year. It has
failed to reach the great majority of its members; it has never attempted hi any discernible way to enforce the policy of intramural
athletics it announced last year. It is unresponsive to Public opinion. It does not get results commensurate with the amount of its
expenditures, which incidentally approximated $5000 in the past year.

failed to meet the emergency—the extraordinary conditions of wartime. It believes that, for the duration of the war, the present athletic board and athletic system should be abolished, that we must
either adopt a more economical and efficient method or discontinue
intercollegiate athletics. We believe that we should retain intercollegiate athletics as long as they are part of an athletic system
which reaches every or almost every member of the student body;
but that they should be discontinued, as a war measure, as soon
as they form the sole activity of the athletic organization. Intercollegiate athletics are an expensive luxury; as an end in themselves,
they should be taboo in war-times—as a means to the end of universal athletic participation, they may be worth their price.
By way of suggestion of a new method, we might mention
Battalion management of athletics. The Battalion is the logical
medium through which universal athletics may be fostered. In this
way, the conflicts between military training and ;team practises
might be obliterated, and an efficient board of management might
be found in the Battalion Staff of Instructors. This, however, is
only a suggestion and should only be taken as such.
Under whatever system athletics are organized, we believe that
the members of the Athletic Association (if their status can be defined) should reserve the right at all times to ratify the appointment of all coo ches; the establishment of new offices, such as assistant graduate manager; and the annual budget.

has expressed by its action the high esteem in which our commandant is held by the undergraduates.

for example, when the military recitations took precedence over all

Raisons d'Etre of Facts.
•

If there is any one single reason for the publication .of the series
of "facts" in these columns it is the additional fact that the athletic
authorities at the University have never felt it necessary to explain
or defend these "facts." The athletic management seems to feel
that, after its mechanical and meaningless annual election, it is absolutely independent and irresponsible. We feel—without the least
personal embitterment and without the least claim of willful negligence—that it is equally inefficient and unsatisfactory and unwilling
or unfit to adjust itself to the changed conditions of war-times.

At the outset, we beg to emphasize that the publication of "facts"
was never aimed at any individual athletic authority, but at the
athletic system. We had no mysterious ulterior purpose. It was
our single object to give publicity to certain conditions and. circumstances which the authorities never saw fit to divulge to the
mere members.. We believe that through publicity alone can the
interest and the sense of responsibility of all members of the Athletic
Association be aroused and sustained. We believe that it is quite
impossible to approve or disapprove the measures and policies of
our representatives unless we know what they have done and what
they are doing. It is by no means our purpose to detract in any
way from the splendid record of our recognized spring team; for
them we have only unstinted praise.
First, we want to introduce some additional "facts" that have
recently come to our attention. Two colleges of the thirteen that
are members, competed in the South Atlantic Intercollegiate Championships at Homewood last Saturday; one of the two was Hopkins.
In his report to the President last fall, the Director of the
Gymnasium said: "It is our desire to get every man in the college
department engaged in some sort of athletic activity, and, with that
end in view, the Athletic Association has engaged for next year the
* * to
services of Mr. R. G. Murphy * * * He comes to us
facilitate a thorough organization amongst the students for active
participation in sports, and to further the interest in all intramural
sport." Mr. Murphy enlisted in the army and was released from
the contract. But the Athletic Association last August, presumably
without the knowledge of either board or sudent body, engaged the
services of the football coach whose last service to Hopkins at that
time might be expressed in the code form: 55 to 0.
In the course of the past winter, it was announced that there
had been. appointed and ratified an assistant graduate 1nanager.
The reasons for and the constitutionality of the appointment were
never discussed.
Now, we are perfectly aware of the Government's whole-hearted
endorsement of intercollegiate athletics during the war. But we
believe that the Government demands, at the same time, increased
economy and efficiency in athletic management; which our own athletic authorities have entirely failed to recognize and enforce.
The Athletic Association has not showed any reasonable tendency to economize. It has arranged long trips, conspicuous among
which are those to Providence and to West Point. It has not withdrawn.the annual appropriation of $75 to the tennis team when it
was perfectly aware that there was no tennis team (we might call
it a tennis clique). It failed to recognize the opportunity to save
$35 by cancelling the Randolph-Macon game; it preferred to pay
$70 and to play the game in the rain before a crowd of three people.
We believe that the members of the Athletic Association would be
interested in a complete, financial statement of the expenditures for
the year, which might be published in these columns and enable the
members to mold their own judgment on the question of economy
-in athletics.
The Athletic Association has not lived up to the standard of
efficiency which was set up for it at the end of last year. It has
failed to reach the great majority of its members; it has never attempted hi any discernible way to enforce the policy of intramural
athletics it announced last year. It is unresponsive to Public opinion. It does not get results commensurate with the amount of its
expenditures, which incidentally approximated $5000 in the past year.
THE NEWS-LETTER believes that the Athletic Association has
•
failed to meet the emergency—the extraordinary conditions of wartime. It believes that, for the duration of the war, the present athletic board and athletic system should be abolished, that we must
either adopt a more economical and efficient method or discontinue
intercollegiate athletics. We believe that we should retain intercollegiate athletics as long as they are part of an athletic system
which reaches every or almost every member of the student body;
but that they should be discontinued, as a war measure, as soon
as they form the sole activity of the athletic organization. Intercollegiate athletics are an expensive luxury; as an end in themselves,
they should be taboo in war-times—as a means to the end of universal athletic participation, they may be worth their price.
By way of suggestion of a new method, we might mention
Battalion management of athletics. The Battalion is the logical
medium through which universal athletics may be fostered. In this
way, the conflicts between military training and ;team practises
might be obliterated, and an efficient board of management might
be found in the Battalion Staff of Instructors. This, however, is
only a suggestion and should only be taken as such.
Under whatever system athletics are organized, we believe that
the members of the Athletic Association (if their status can be defined) should reserve the right at all times to ratify the appointment of all coo ches; the establishment of new offices, such as assistant graduate manager; and the annual budget.

A sceptre o'er her spotless shield.
The stars blaze east across the flood,
To fields enriched with martyrs' blood,
Where heroes brave the molten rain—
They call and must not call in vain.
Untainted by a hireling's wage,
Unstirred by hate, by ruthless rage,
Firm be the hand and sure the thrust
To rout the hosts of loot and lust.
She craves no homage born of fears;
She seeks no tribute stained with tears;
But brings to those who would be free
Her priceless boon of Liberty.
'Tis hers to aid the sore oppressed;
To prove the faith by lips professed;
To rend the scourge—to break the rod.
Who fights for Freedom, fights for God.
